text:
Assume $f(x) = x^2$ for some integer $x$. Then $f(x+1) = f(x)+f(1)+2x = x^2+1+2x = (x+1)^2$.
Since $f(0) = 0$, $f(1)=1$, it follows by induction that $f(x)=x^2$ for all $x \in \mathbb{N}$.
Since $f(x)+f(-x) = 2x^2$, $f(x)=x^2 \implies f(-x) = 2x^2-f(x) = 2x^2-x^2 = x^2$.
Thus $f(x)=x^2$ for all integers $x$.
